This fruit is crisp and juicy with a sweet-tart flavor. It has a bright red or green skin and a firm, white flesh. Rich in vitamin C and fiber.
A citrus fruit with a bright orange, easy-to-peel skin. The segments are juicy, sweet, and slightly tangy. High in vitamin C and antioxidants.
Large and oblong with a green rind and bright red, watery flesh. Very sweet with a high water content. Contains vitamins A and C.
Long and curved with a yellow peel that turns brown as it ripens. Soft, creamy flesh with a sweet taste. High in potassium and vitamin B6.
Firm texture with a balance of sweetness and acidity. Skin can be red, yellow, or green. Contains pectin and vitamin K.
Round with a dimpled skin that's aromatic when peeled. Pulpy segments burst with sweet-tart juice. Excellent source of folate.
Refreshingly sweet with a crisp texture. Green-striped exterior hides seed-speckled red flesh. Rich in lycopene and hydration.
Easy to peel with a smooth, starchy-sweet flesh. Naturally wrapped in a thick yellow skin. Good source of magnesium and fiber.
Classic fruit with a satisfying crunch. Skin ranges from deep crimson to golden. Contains quercetin and vitamin E.
Zesty fragrance with a perfect sweet-sour balance. Easy to separate into wedges. Packed with immune-boosting nutrients.
Summery fruit that's 92% water. Pink-red interior with black seeds. Contains citrulline and electrolytes.
Energy-dense with a creamy consistency. Peel changes from green to yellow to spotted. High in tryptophan and quick sugars.
Distinctive floral aroma when sliced. White flesh oxidizes quickly. Contains malic acid and polyphenols.
Sun-kissed citrus with oil glands visible in the peel. Juice vesicles packed with flavor. Rich in thiamine and flavonoids.
Large melon with a waxy green exterior. Crisp, granular flesh that's thirst-quenching. Good source of vitamin B5.
Tropical fruit that ripens at room temperature. Soft texture perfect for smoothies. Contains dopamine and natural sugars.
Waxy skin protects the dense, airy flesh inside. Flavor profile ranges from honey-sweet to winey. High in boron.
Globular fruit that's heavy for its size. Albedo (white pith) is bitter but nutritious. Excellent vitamin C delivery.
Picnic favorite with a hard green shell. Juicy flesh can be seedless or contain black seeds. Rich in amino acids.
Convenient natural snack in its own packaging. Texture becomes softer as it ripens. High in prebiotic fiber.
Popular in pies due to its firmness when cooked. Skin may be glossy or matte. Contains catechin antioxidants.
Winter citrus that's easy to segment. Essential oils in the peel used for flavoring. Packed with hesperidin.
Cylindrical or round with light and dark green stripes. Flesh can be yellow in some varieties. Contains choline.
Starchy when green, becoming sweeter with age. Grows in large hanging clusters. Good source of vitamin B2.
Some varieties have russeted patches on skin. Flesh resists browning in some cultivars. Contains ursolic acid.
Navels have that distinctive belly-button formation. Juice is less acidic than other citrus. High in pectin.
Can weigh up to 20 pounds when mature. Rind sometimes pickled. Contains glutathione antioxidant.
Natural athletes' food due to quick energy. Bruises easily when handled roughly. Rich in manganese.
Core contains small black seeds. Stem attaches at indented top. Good source of vitamin A precursors.
Valencia types are best for juicing. Oil in peel can cause photosensitivity. Contains calcium.
Thumping the rind indicates ripeness. Yellow spot shows where it rested on ground. Rich in beta-carotene.
Tapered ends with longitudinal ridges. Grows in hands' of 10-20. Contains serotonin precursors.
Some varieties have slight floral notes. Skin texture can be smooth or slightly rough. High in kaempferol.
Blood varieties have crimson flesh. Pith contains bioflavonoids. Excellent source of pantothenic acid.
Square varieties grown in Japan for space efficiency. Rind sometimes used in stir-fries. Contains copper.
Plantain varieties are starchier. Sap stains clothing. Good source of vitamin B3.
Fuji types are exceptionally sweet. Bloom is the natural waxy coating. Contains chlorogenic acid.
Cara cara has pinkish-red flesh. Easier to digest than many fruits. Rich in cryptoxanthin.
Icebox types are personal-sized. Webbing on rind indicates sugar content. Contains silicon.
Red varieties have burgundy skin. More antioxidants than yellow types. High in vitamin B9.
Some heirlooms have complex flavor profiles. Stem releases when fully ripe. Contains phloridzin.
Seville types are bitter, used for marmalade. Loose skin indicates juiciness. Rich in limonene.
Seedless varieties are sterile hybrids. Hollow sound when tapped means ripe. Contains L-citrulline.
Blue Java has ice cream texture when ripe. More aromatic than common types. High in pectin.
Some varieties resist browning when cut. Skin contains most nutrients. Rich in myricetin.
Bergamot used for Earl Grey tea. Smaller than eating oranges. Contains naringin.
Yellow Crimson has sunny-colored flesh. Rind can be candied. Rich in phenolics.
Manzano has apple-like taste when ripe. Shorter and stubbier shape. Contains fructooligosaccharides.
Winesap has wine-like aftertaste. Keeps well in storage. Contains anthocyanins.
Tangerine hybrids are easier to peel. Loses acidity as it ripens. Rich in lutein.
